data.title: Thousands queue to pay respects to late Thai king
data.description:
(26 Sep 2017) Ten of thousands of people waited outside Thailand's Grand Palace on Monday to pay their last respects to the late King. 
Over 11 million people have come to mourn the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej since he passed away on 13 October last year.
The number of people has increased dramatically this week after the Royal Household Bureau announced that this Saturday will be the final day that people would be allowed to pray in front of the Royal Urn at the Palace. 
This group of mourners sitting behind the waiting line arrived at the Royal Plaza in the early hours of Monday and they are expected to wait until evening before it would be their turn to go in. 
Thai officials said more than 64,000 people came to mourn their late King on Sunday.
Preparations for the royal crematorium are now considered finished, according to General Tanasak Patimapragorn, Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister. 
The design of the crematorium represents a mystical Mount Meru from Buddhist and Hindu legends where gods reside. 
King Maha Vajiralongkorn will preside at an official ceremony on 18 October to install the royal nine-tier umbrella on top of the structure, signifying the finishing of the crematorium. 
The funeral will be held on 26 October this year.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/57698cc73a839e5fc3a2a0a3fcf1d8cf 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Suicide bomb targets foreign forces in Kabul
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) Afghanistan's Interior Ministry said on Sunday a suicide car bomber has struck a convoy of international forces in the capital, wounding three civilians.
The ministry's statement did not provide further details on Sunday's attack. 
No one claimed responsibility, but the Taliban and an Islamic State affiliate have repeatedly targeted Afghan and foreign forces in recent years.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/19853e878d89e50b7ba46c50a76b6341 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Schulz: many German voters still undecided
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) Germany's Social Democrats (SPD) top candidate Martin Schulz said on Sunday he was hoping many undecided voters would vote for his party in the country's national election. 
Schulz voted in Wuerselen, the city where her served as mayor for more than a decade.
He is Chancellor Angela Merkel's main challenger.
Pollsters said earlier in the week that many voters had remained undecided until the very last moment. 
But Merkel was widely expected to win a fourth term in office as Germans went to the polls on Sunday in an election that is also likely to see the farthest right-wing party in 60 years, the anti-migrant Alternative for Germany, win seats in parliament.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/41d338a76efca50cb5f8667d3f38cd85 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: The race for German electoral victory gets underway
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) German voters were casting their ballots on Sunday morning in the country's national election in which Chancellor Angela Merkel is seeking a fourth term. 
Final preparations were also underway for the 44th 'BMW Berlin Marathon', expected to take place later on the day. 
Merkel's conservative bloc of the Christian Democratic Party and Bavarian-only Christian Social Union has a healthy lead in the polls.
Merkel's main challenger is Social Democrat Martin Schulz. 
German voters will elect their new parliament on Sunday, but don't expect a new government to be in place next week.
With the seats expected to be spread across up to six caucuses, there's very little chance of anyone winning a majority to govern alone. 
After voters have had their say, it's down to Germany's political parties to put together a coalition to govern for the next four years.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/b967692e3a3db68ca5e40e3645c232d4 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: First-time AfD lawmakers meet in Berlin
data.description:
(26 Sep 2017) Lawmakers for the nationalist, anti-migrant Alternative for Germany, or AfD, who have entered parliament for the first time, met in Berlin on Tuesday.
German parties' newly elected parliamentary groups are holding their first meetings after an election that left Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservative bloc weakened, but still on top.
It now faces a complicated task of forming a coalition government and the prospect of robust opposition from both the right and left.
The most politically plausible option for the next government led by Merkel is a three-way coalition with the pro-business Free Democrats and the traditionally left-leaning Greens.
Merkel has said she wants to seek talks with them, but also with her former coalition partner, the Social Democrats who say they will go into opposition.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/102a648f0e6ab7d0e274015471ca477a 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: German voters assess Schulz's chances
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) German voters on Sunday were casting their ballots in the country's national election in the small town of Wuerselen, where chancellor candidate Martin Schulz was expected to vote later that day. 
Wuerselen is the city where Schulz served as mayor for more than a decade. 
Germany's Social Democrats (SPD) top candidate is Chancellor Angela Merkel main challenger. 
Merkel's conservative bloc of the Christian Democratic Party and Bavarian-only Christian Social Union has a healthy lead in the polls.
German voters will elect their new parliament on Sunday, but don't expect a new government to be in place next week.
With the seats expected to be spread across up to six caucuses, there's very little chance of anyone winning a majority to govern alone. 
After voters have had their say, it's down to Germany's political parties to put together a coalition to govern for the next four years.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/c12e64c18155b897fdd72f50c24facb7 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Vaccinations in Manila ahead of World Rabies Day
data.description:
(26 Sep 2017) Dog owners in Manila had their pets vaccinated against rabies on Tuesday in a day of action and awareness for rabies prevention.
Members of the Humane Society International (HSI) carried out the vaccination programme in observance of World Rabies Day on September 28.
The Philippines has the fifth highest rate of rabies in the world, with between 200 and 300 human rabies deaths reported every year, according to Humane Society International. 
HSI went house-to-house in a Manila neighbourhood to make sure every dog got the anti-rabies vaccine.
Last year, HSI vaccinated 16,126 dogs in 21 days, and ever since there has been no confirmed rabies cases in the area.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/a157fc23b28ea7ae7200f64197a518ea 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: North Iraq prepares for independence vote
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) Iraq's Kurds were preparing on Sunday to vote in a referendum to decide whether they should secede from Iraq.
Irbil, the capital of the Kurdish region of Iraq, has been decorated with Kurdish flags and residents are preparing to have their say.
The vote, which is due to go ahead on Monday, has stirred passions in the semi-autonomous region which has long had a troubled relationship with the central government.
No polls have been published but the referendum result is expected to be overwhelmingly in favour of independence.
The referendum has been dismissed by Baghdad as destabilising and illegal.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/9903d4c7d2dda7f698e80f6a9c328f79 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Ballot boxes are readied for Kurdish vote
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) Ballot papers were being prepared in Irbil on Sunday, one day before Iraq's Kurds were expected to vote in a referendum to decide whether they should secede from Iraq.
A school in the Christian neighbourhood of Ankawa was emptying classrooms and getting ballot boxes ready. 
Election officer Nobil Boutros said election material had been received. 
Irbil is the capital of the semi-autonomous Kurdish region of Iraq.
The vote, which is due to go ahead on Monday, has stirred passions in the semi-autonomous region which has long had a troubled relationship with the central government.
No polls have been published but the referendum result is expected to be overwhelmingly in favour of independence.
The referendum has been dismissed by Baghdad as destabilising and illegal.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/de193aea9d270688d0cdb65403752a18 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Going deaf has sharpened my art, David Hockney says at Pompidou Center unveiling
data.description:
(26 Sep 2017) ACCLAIMED ARTIST DAVID HOCKNEY UNVEILS HUGE PAINTING HE IS DONATING TO POMPIDOU CENTER
Renowned British painter David Hockney unveiled the huge painting he is donating to the Pompidou Center in Paris, Tuesday (26 SEPT. 2017).
Titled "The Arrival of Spring in Woldgate, East Yorkshire," the 2011 painting includes 32 panels stretching more than three meters high and nearly 10 meters wide. 
The work goes on display this week as part of a traveling retrospective of the 80-year-old's work.
"The Spring was an excitement for me because, having lived in California for 25 years, where there really is not much Spring, it's tropical really, and the Spring was very exciting for me to watch so that's what it was," explained Hockney.
Hockney is an innovator whose 60-year career has taken in sketching, painting, printmaking, photography and digital iPad experiments. 
His depictions of sun-dappled Los Angeles swimming pools and wooded Yorkshire hills are among the best-known images in contemporary art.
Hockney says his hearing loss has helped sharpen his sense of space and perspective.
"If you lose one sense, you gain other senses, and I feel I could see space clearer. I put it down to the hearing loss. ... I can't tell what sound is coming from where."
The artist, who continues to paint, described his most recent project.
"I'm working on reverse perspective paintings. I've done quite a few actually. I'm very excited by it actually. I've just done about six big paintings. I'm very excited by it."


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/15e7f695651c0677a9de1b560d470604 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Search for quake victims continues in Mexico
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) The search continued on Sunday for survivors and the bodies of people who died in quake-collapsed buildings in Mexico City.
Meanwhile, thousands of people have been left homeless because their houses or apartment buildings are uninhabitable. 
Specialists are fanning out to inspect buildings and determine which are unsafe after Tuesday's magnitude 7.1 earthquake, which killed at least 307 - more than half of them in the capital.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/511d9a16c835add5ab4398169f9d09e6 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Scuffles amid protest outside AfD HQ in Berlin
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) Protesters gathered outside the headquarters of the anti-migrant Alternative for Germany Party, as election polls indicated they'd emerged as the third-strongest party in Germany's election.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/2fc9dec5a16eead80a347820c3b35284

data.title: Kirkuk residents divided ahead of Kurdish vote
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) Kurds, Turkmen and Arabs living in the disputed city of Kirkuk have mixed opinions regarding Monday's vote by Iraq's Kurds on support for independence. 
The forthcoming referendum has stirred fears of instability across the region as the war against the Islamic State group winds down. 
Kirkuk is disputed by the central and Kurdish regional governments but has been under Kurdish control since 2014 when Iraqi forces fled the city from advancing Islamic State group militants.
The Kurds are likely to approve the referendum, but the non-binding vote is not expected to result in any formal declaration of independence.
Ali Hussein, a displaced Arab man from Hawija now living in Kirkuk, said he was afraid the Kurds would deport him after a 'yes' vote. 
Other Kirkuk citizens are afraid tensions between the different groups will rise after the vote. 
Clashes have already erupted several times between Kurds and Turkmen following heated pro-independence demonstrations.
Many Turkmen and Arabs say they've been shut out of power since the Kurds took control.
The United Sates and the United Nations have condemned the referendum.
Turkey, which is battling its own Kurdish insurgency, has threatened to use military force to prevent the emergence of an independent Kurdish state, and Baghdad has warned it will respond militarily to any violence resulting from the vote.
Initial results from the poll are expected on Tuesday, with the official results announced later in the week.
Denied independence when colonial powers drew the map of the Middle East after World War I, the Kurds form a sizable minority in Turkey, Iran, Syria, and Iraq. 
They have long been at odds with the Baghdad government over the sharing of oil revenues and the fate of disputed territories like the city of Kirkuk.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/bd89016efa83c174f1e50e5b76052176 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

asset.title: Kirkuk residents divided ahead of Kurdish vote
asset.description:
(24 Sep 2017) Kurds, Turkmen and Arabs living in the disputed city of Kirkuk have mixed opinions regarding Monday's vote by Iraq's Kurds on support for independence. 
The forthcoming referendum has stirred fears of instability across the region as the war against the Islamic State group winds down. 
Kirkuk is disputed by the central and Kurdish regional governments but has been under Kurdish control since 2014 when Iraqi forces fled the city from advancing Islamic State group militants.
The Kurds are likely to approve the referendum, but the non-binding vote is not expected to result in any formal declaration of independence.
Ali Hussein, a displaced Arab man from Hawija now living in Kirkuk, said he was afraid the Kurds would deport him after a 'yes' vote. 
Other Kirkuk citizens are afraid tensions between the different groups will rise after the vote. 
Clashes have already erupted several times between Kurds and Turkmen following heated pro-independence demonstrations.
Many Turkmen and Arabs say they've been shut out of power since the Kurds took control.
The United Sates and the United Nations have condemned the referendum.
Turkey, which is battling its own Kurdish insurgency, has threatened to use military force to prevent the emergence of an independent Kurdish state, and Baghdad has warned it will respond militarily to any violence resulting from the vote.
Initial results from the poll are expected on Tuesday, with the official results announced later in the week.
Denied independence when colonial powers drew the map of the Middle East after World War I, the Kurds form a sizable minority in Turkey, Iran, Syria, and Iraq. 
They have long been at odds with the Baghdad government over the sharing of oil revenues and the fate of disputed territories like the city of Kirkuk.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/bd89016efa83c174f1e50e5b76052176 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
asset.author: AP Archive

data.title: Iran puts missiles on public display in Tehran
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) Iran's elite Revolutionary Guard (IRGC) has displayed the country's sophisticated Russian-made S-300 air defense system in central Tehran.
This is the first time that the S-300 air defense system has been displayed in public.
The public show in Tehran's Baharestan square near the Parliament building square exhibited different missile systems, including ballistic missiles, solid-fuel surface-to-surface Sejjil missiles and the liquid-fuel Ghadr.
The IRGC prepared the show for the annual Defense Week, marking the 37th anniversary of the 1980s Iran-Iraq war. 
U.S. President Donald Trump signed in August a bill imposing mandatory penalties on those involved in Iran's controversial ballistic missile programme and anyone who does business with them.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/a987eefe1a668a663a93d6210c5ebcfe 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Global community meets to talk funding for Syria crisis
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) LEADIN:
Jordanian government, United Nations organisations and representatives from donor countries participated in a three-day workshop to discuss the funding needed to cover the annual Jordan Response Plan for Syria Crisis for the years 2018-2020. 
Only 18 percent of the money needed for the 2017 plan has been received so far. Jordan hopes to receive two-third of committed funds from donors by the end of this year. 
STORYLINE:
These people are here for one reason - to tackle the Syrian crisis.
They've gathered at the Dead Sea to update the Jordan Response Plan - the framework that deals with the Syrian crisis - for the years 2018-2020.
The initiative aims to put this plan on the global agenda every year to generate enough funding where it is badly needed.  
And Jordan's Planning Minister Imad Fakhoury says a lot more money is needed to reach this year's target.
"The fund registered for the response plan is still at the 18 percent, and it is low, but usually in the last four months of each year the numbers increase," he says. 
"We've reminded the international community when they pledged at the Brussels Conference in April of the importance of having the same percentage of funds presented in the last year which is close to two-thirds of this support."
Jordan received 62 percent of the donors committed fund in 2016. 
The representative of EU donors countries, Ibrahim Laafia, says donors are planning to give 1.3 billion US dollars. 
"At this stage of the crisis, as complex as it is, we should be able to prioritise needs based on evidence, therefore a realistic prioritisation of needs based on sound assessment of results will allow donors and partners to focus on the most important priorities and therefore be more responsive."
According to Jordanian officials, Jordan hosts 13 percent of the world's registered refugees. More than 1.3 million Syrian refugees live in camps and within host communities. 
Around 660,000 Syrian refugees are registered with UNHCR.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/29adbf1985db7aef220000dd780cdfa6 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: British actor, director Fiennes gets his Serbian passport
data.description:
(24 Sep 2017) BRITISH ACTOR, DIRECTOR FIENNES GETS HIS SERBIAN PASSPORT
British actor and director Ralph Fiennes has received a Serbian passport from the Balkan country's president after he was granted citizenship earlier this month.
President Aleksandar Vucic handed the passport to Fiennes at a meeting Sunday (24 SEPT. 2017) in the Serbian presidency building in Belgrade. Vucic says "we Serbs are happy to have you as a friend and now a fellow citizen."
Fiennes first came to Serbia in 2010 to shoot his directorial debut, an adaptation of William Shakespeare's "Coriolanus." Fiennes is currently filming a movie in Belgrade on Soviet ballet dancing legend Rudolf Nureyev.
Fiennes also attended an inauguration ceremony for Vucic in June.
American action hero Steven Seagal is among other film celebrities who have been granted Serbian citizenship in the past.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/a9b785112f88dff21fef36415e45ab56 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
